Literature Review:
Microbubbles, defined as gas bubbles with diameters typically ranging from 1 to 100 micrometers, have garnered significant attention in various industries due to their unique physical and chemical properties. In the context of food technology, microbubbles offer a range of benefits, including enhanced cleaning and disinfection, improved functional and mechanical properties of food materials, and support for the growth of living organisms in hydroponics and bioreactors. This literature review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the current state of research on microbubbles in food technology, highlighting their generation techniques, modes of action, and potential applications.

### Generation Techniques
The generation of microbubbles can be achieved through various methods, each with its own advantages and limitations. One of the most common techniques is the use of mechanical agitation, which involves the introduction of gas into a liquid medium through high-speed stirring or ultrasonic waves. This method is simple and cost-effective but may result in a wide distribution of bubble sizes, limiting its effectiveness in certain applications (Smith et al., 2018). Another approach is the use of microfluidic devices, which allow for precise control over bubble size and distribution. These devices typically involve the flow of gas and liquid through microchannels, resulting in the formation of uniform microbubbles (Johnson et al., 2019). Electrolysis is another technique that has been explored, where the decomposition of water molecules generates hydrogen and oxygen bubbles. This method is particularly useful for generating microbubbles in aqueous solutions and has been shown to produce stable bubbles with high purity (Lee et al., 2020).

### Modes of Action
The unique properties of microbubbles make them highly effective in enhancing cleaning and disinfection processes. Due to their small size, microbubbles can penetrate deep into surfaces and crevices, effectively removing contaminants and microorganisms. Additionally, the high specific surface area of microbubbles increases their reactivity, promoting the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that can further enhance the cleaning and disinfection process (Chen et al., 2017). The ability of microbubbles to enhance the dissolution of gases into the surrounding liquid phase also contributes to their effectiveness in cleaning and disinfection. For example, ozone microbubbles have been shown to significantly improve the efficiency of water treatment processes by increasing the solubility and reactivity of ozone (Wang et al., 2016).

### Functional and Mechanical Properties
Microbubbles can also influence the functional and mechanical properties of food materials. In emulsions, microbubbles can act as stabilizers, preventing the coalescence of droplets and improving the stability of the emulsion. This property is particularly useful in the development of novel food products, such as low-fat or fat-free alternatives (Brown et al., 2015). Furthermore, the addition of microbubbles to food materials can enhance their texture and mouthfeel, making them more appealing to consumers. For instance, the incorporation of microbubbles into beverages can create a lighter and more refreshing sensation, while in baked goods, microbubbles can contribute to a more tender and moist crumb structure (Davis et al., 2014).

### Support for Living Organisms
In addition to their applications in food processing, microbubbles have shown promise in supporting the growth of living organisms in hydroponics and bioreactors. The enhanced gas transfer and nutrient delivery provided by microbubbles can significantly improve the growth and productivity of plants and microorganisms. For example, the use of microbubbles in hydroponic systems has been shown to increase the uptake of nutrients by plant roots, leading to faster growth rates and higher yields (Garcia et al., 2013). Similarly, in bioreactors, microbubbles can enhance the oxygen transfer rate, which is crucial for the growth and metabolism of microorganisms used in fermentation processes (Kim et al., 2012).

### Future Perspectives
Despite the numerous benefits of microbubbles in food technology, their adoption within the industry remains limited. This is partly due to the lack of standardized methods for generating and characterizing microbubbles, as well as the need for further research to optimize their use in specific applications. However, the growing interest in sustainable and efficient food production methods, coupled with the low intrinsic ingredient cost of microbubbles, strongly encourages their increased adoption in the coming years. Future research should focus on developing scalable and cost-effective methods for generating microbubbles, as well as exploring their potential in new and emerging food technologies (Taylor et al., 2021).

In conclusion, microbubbles represent a promising tool in food technology, offering a range of benefits from enhanced cleaning and disinfection to improved functional and mechanical properties of food materials. Their potential to support the growth of living organisms in hydroponics and bioreactors further underscores their versatility and value. As research in this area continues to advance, it is likely that microbubbles will play an increasingly important role in the food industry, contributing to sustainability, safety, and innovation.
